text: DISCUSSION

This study demonstrates that <extra_id_0> RUNX transcription factors 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> 3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> play an important role in the generation of <extra_id_0> FOXP3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + iT reg cells by TGF-beta .

<extra_id_0> TGF-beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mediates <extra_id_0> RUNX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induction and <extra_id_0> FOXP3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is efficiently up-regulated by <extra_id_0> RUNX1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> RUNX3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in human <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells .

text: There are three putative RUNX binding sites in the proximal <extra_id_0> FOXP3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter .
One binding site was predicted as a binding site for <extra_id_0> RUNX2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Promoter enzyme immunoassay results showed that binding of <extra_id_0> RUNX1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> RUNX3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> also occurred at this site ( as well as at the other two ) , which were initially identified as RUNX1 binding sites .

This finding is not surprising because <extra_id_0> RUNX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> proteins bind to promoter or enhancer elements of their target genes via the runt domain , which is conserved between members of the <extra_id_0> RUNX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> family .

The <extra_id_0> RUNX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein that actually induces the expression of <extra_id_0> FOXP3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> might therefore be dependent on the availability of the specific <extra_id_0> RUNX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> family member at certain stages of T cell development .

text: <extra_id_0> RUNX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> proteins are able to increase or inhibit transcriptional activity of their target genes depending on the cell type and the target gene ( Otto et al . , 2003 ) .

Mutation of only one of the three binding sites had only a little effect on the promoter activity ; however , when two binding sites were mutated , the <extra_id_0> FOXP3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity dropped to a greater extent .
The most striking effect was observed when all three binding sites were mutated .
We therefore assume that these binding sites have partially redundant functions , but binding to at least two sites seems to be necessary for full promoter activation .

text: <extra_id_0> TGF-beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promotes or inhibits the proliferation , differentiation , and survival of a wide array of different cells .
It is also produced in activated T cells and it inhibits T cell proliferation ( Kehrl et al . , 1986 ; Siegel and Massague , 2003 ) .

It was shown that <extra_id_0> TGF-beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is mandatory for the maintenance of peripheral T reg cells and their expression of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( Marie et al . , 2005 ; Rubtsov and Rudensky , 2007 ) .

<extra_id_0> RUNX3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> plays an important role in <extra_id_0> TGF-beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated growth control in epithelial cells , as loss of <extra_id_0> RUNX3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> leads to decreased sensitivity to <extra_id_0> TGF-beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and hyperproliferation of the gastric mucosa ( Blyth et al . , 2005 ) .

text: Retinoic acid is secreted by a subset of dendritic cells in the gut - associated lymphoid tissue .

It inhibits the <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - driven induction of Th17 cells and facilitates the differentiation of naive T cells to <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T reg cells ( Mucida et al . , 2007 ) .

text: The involvement of <extra_id_0> RUNX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> proteins in autoimmune diseases has been previously suggested ( Alarcon-Riquelme , 2003 ) .

A mutation in the RUNX1 binding site in the promoter of <extra_id_0> programmed cell death 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene ( <extra_id_0> PDCD-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) has been implicated in systemic lupus erythematosus pathogenesis ( Prokunina et al . , 2002 ) .

<extra_id_0> Runx1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> regulates the transitions of developing thymocytes from the <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - <extra_id_0> CD8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - double-negative stage to the <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + <extra_id_0> CD8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + double-positive stage and from the DP stage to the mature single - positive stage ( Egawa et al . , 2007 ) .

<extra_id_0> Runx1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Runx3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> deficiencies caused marked reductions in mature thymocytes and T cells of the <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + helper and <extra_id_0> CD8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + cytotoxic T cell lineages .
